content.question: Lewis diagrams of the weak bases <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="N F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown above. Based on these diagrams, which of the following predictions of their relative base strength is correct, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="N F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is a stronger base than <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because more than one resonance structure exists for its conjugate acid <math alttext="N F 3 H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, making it more stable than <math alttext="N H 4 with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is a stronger base than <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because of the greater electronegativity of <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></math> compared with <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is a weaker base than <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because of the greater electronegativity of <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> compared with <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is a weaker base than <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because more than one resonance structure exists for its conjugate acid <math alttext="N F 3 H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, making it more stable than <math alttext="N H 4 with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="N F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is a weaker base than <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> because of the greater electronegativity of <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> compared with <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 8.6: Molecular Structure of Acids and Bases

skill.text: 6.C: Support a claim with evidence from representations or models at the particulate level, such as the structure of atoms and/or molecules.
